skill.name: chrome-devtools-debugging
skill.description: Debug and analyze web applications using Chrome DevTools MCP. Use for console log inspection, network request monitoring, performance analysis, and debugging authenticated sessions. For basic browser automation (screenshots, form filling), use browser-discovery skill instead.
skill.summary: Debug and analyze web applications using Chrome DevTools MCP. Use for console log inspection, network request monitoring, performance analysis, and debugging authenticated sessions.
skill.author: Consiliency

security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate Chrome DevTools debugging skill. All static findings are false positives. The 'external_commands' detections are markdown code fences in documentation, not actual shell execution. 'Browser storage access' references are legitimate DevTools debugging operations for inspecting localStorage/sessionStorage during authenticated session debugging. 'Weak cryptographic algorithm' flags are triggered by security-related documentation content, not actual crypto implementation. No malicious code patterns found.

content.user_title: Debug Web Apps with Chrome DevTools
content.value_statement: Web application debugging requires inspecting console errors, network requests, and authenticated sessions. This skill provides structured access to Chrome DevTools MCP for automated debugging workflows, performance analysis, and JavaScript execution in browser context.
actual_capabilities: Inspect console errors, warnings, and log messages from Chrome DevTools Protocol
Monitor and analyze network requests including XHR, fetch, headers, and response bodies
Execute JavaScript code directly in browser context via evaluate_script
Debug authenticated sessions by inspecting localStorage and sessionStorage
Record and analyze performance traces with AI-powered insights
Navigate pages, list tabs, and wait for page elements to load
limitations: Requires Chrome browser running with remote debugging enabled on port 9222
Cannot take screenshots or perform basic browser automation (use browser-discovery skill instead)
Cannot modify browser settings or install extensions
Depends on chrome-devtools-mcp server being installed and accessible

use_cases.title: Debug JavaScript errors in production
use_cases.description: Quickly identify and diagnose console errors in deployed web applications without manual browser inspection. Connect to a running Chrome instance and retrieve all error messages with stack traces.

use_cases.title: Analyze API request failures
use_cases.description: Correlate console errors with failed network requests to identify API issues. Get full request and response details including headers, status codes, and response bodies.

use_cases.title: Debug authenticated user sessions
use_cases.description: Connect to an existing Chrome browser with a logged-in user and inspect authentication state. Examine localStorage for tokens and sessionStorage for session data.

prompt_templates.title: Get all console errors
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all console errors from the Chrome DevTools session. List each error with its message and timestamp if available.
prompt_templates.scenario: Initial error inspection when debugging a web application

prompt_templates.title: Find failed API requests
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me all failed network requests (4xx or 5xx status codes) from the browser. Include the request URL, status code, and response body for each.

prompt_templates.title: Check authenticated session state
prompt_templates.prompt: Inspect the authenticated session. Get all items from localStorage and sessionStorage, and list any authentication tokens or user data found.

prompt_templates.title: Performance analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: Start a performance trace, reload the page, and stop the trace. Then get the AI-powered insights about performance bottlenecks.
prompt_templates.scenario: Identifying performance issues in web applications

output: 1. TypeError: Cannot read property 'data' of undefined

best_practices: Start Chrome with remote debugging before connecting: google-chrome --remote-debugging-port=9222
Set the CHROME_DEVTOOLS_URL environment variable to point to your Chrome instance
Use pagination (page_size, page_idx) when working with large numbers of console messages or network requests
Combine console and network tools to correlate errors with failed API calls
anti_patterns: Using this skill for screenshots or form filling (use browser-discovery skill instead)
Trying to connect before starting Chrome with --remote-debugging-port=9222
Calling tools without waiting for page load to complete
Assuming the skill can debug non-Chrome browsers

faq.question: How do I start Chrome for debugging?
faq.answer: Start Chrome with remote debugging enabled: google-chrome --remote-debugging-port=9222 on Linux, or /Applications/Google\ Chrome.app/Contents/MacOS/Google\ Chrome --remote-debugging-port=9222 on macOS.

faq.question: What is the difference between this and browser-discovery?
faq.answer: This skill focuses on debugging and analysis (console inspection, network monitoring, performance tracing). browser-discovery is for basic browser automation like screenshots, form filling, and navigation.

faq.question: Can I debug an incognito window?
faq.answer: Yes, but you need to start Chrome with --remote-debugging-port=9222 using your normal profile or specify --user-data-dir for a specific profile.

faq.question: How do I inspect localStorage data?
faq.answer: Use the debug.evaluate_script tool with the expression JSON.stringify(localStorage) to retrieve all localStorage items as a JSON string.

faq.question: Can this skill modify page content?
faq.answer: The evaluate_script function can execute JavaScript that modifies the page, but it is primarily designed for reading data and debugging purposes.

faq.question: Does this work with other browsers?
faq.answer: No, this skill specifically uses Chrome DevTools Protocol. Other browsers like Firefox or Safari have different debugging protocols.
